summary: Lung cancer is a malignant tumor that originates in the tissues of the lungs, typically in the cells lining the air passages. It is the leading cause of cancer death worldwide. The disease is primarily caused by genetic damage to lung cells, often induced by inhaling toxic substances like cigarette smoke. Damaged cells multiply uncontrollably, forming tumors that can spread within the lungs and metastasize to other parts of the body, impairing lung function and eventually leading to death if untreated. There are two main types: small cell lung cancer (SCLC) and non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), which differ in their growth patterns and treatment responses.
causes: Genetic damage to DNA of lung cells
Indoor air pollution (burning wood, charcoal, crop residue)
Inactivation of p53 tumor suppressor gene
Inactivation of RB tumor suppressor gene
Loss of tumor suppressor genes on chromosome 3
risk_factors: Radiation therapy to the breast or chest
High consumption of nitrosamines and nitrites
Being overweight (possibly due to smoking-related lower body weight)
Older age (average age at diagnosis is 70)
Male sex (historically, but varies by geography)
symptoms: Swelling in the face and/or veins in the neck (superior vena cava syndrome)
Horner's syndrome (drooping eyelid, constricted pupil, decreased sweating on one side of the face)
Leukoerythroblastosis (immature cells in the blood, with bone marrow metastasis)
Pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen (with liver metastases)
Hypertrophic pulmonary osteoarthropathy (nail clubbing, joint soreness, skin thickening)
Autoimmune deterioration of cerebellum, limbic system, or brainstem
Paraneoplastic blood clotting (migratory venous thrombophlebitis, clots in the heart, disseminated intravascular coagulation)
diagnosis: Histological examination of biopsy by a pathologist
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain
treatments: Surgery (tumor removal, lobectomy, wedge resection, segmentectomy, pneumonectomy)
Chemotherapy (cisplatin, carboplatin, etoposide, irinotecan, topotecan, lurbinectedin, paclitaxel, docetaxel, vinorelbine, gemcitabine, pemetrexed)

Targeted therapy (EGFR inhibitors: osimertinib, erlotinib, gefitinib, afatinib, dacomitinib; ALK inhibitors: crizotinib, alectinib, brigatinib, ceritinib, lorlatinib; MET inhibitors: capmatinib, tepotinib; BRAF inhibitors: dabrafenib; MEK inhibitors: trametinib; ROS1 inhibitors: crizotinib, lorlatinib, entrectinib; NTRK inhibitors: entrectinib, larotrectinib; RET inhibitors: selpercatinib)
Immunotherapy (immune checkpoint inhibitors: durvalumab, pembrolizumab, atezolizumab, nivolumab plus ipilimumab)
Neuropathic agents (anticonvulsants, tricyclic antidepressants, serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors)
